The Planck Institute for Biogeochemistry has conducted research on the impact of climate change on wildﬁre activity. Climate change is expected to exacerbate wildﬁre activity through the worsening of fire weather. Improving our ability to anticipate wildﬁres on a global scale is crucial for mitigating their negative effects. This study creates a global fire dataset and demonstrates a prototype for predicting the presence of global burned areas on a sub-seasonal scale using segmentation deep learning models. A global analysis-ready datacube is presented, containing variables related to seasonal and sub-seasonal fire drivers, including climate, vegetation, oceanic indices, and human-related variables, as well as historical burned areas and wildﬁre emissions from 2001 to 2021. A deep learning model is trained to predict the presence of burned areas 8, 16, 32, and 64 days in advance.

Fire is a fundamental process in the Earth system, playing a crucial role in shaping ecosystems worldwide. While traditionally considered a net carbon-neutral process in the long term, climate change can alter this balance by exacerbating fire weather, leading to increased global fire activity. The expansion of fires to evergreen forests can weaken their carbon sink status, releasing stored carbon into the atmosphere, which in turn contributes to climate change. Wildﬁres pose a significant natural hazard globally, causing loss of lives, properties, infrastructure, and ecosystem services. As climate and human activity increasingly affect fire regimes worldwide, it is essential to improve our understanding and anticipation capabilities of the wildﬁre phenomenon in the Earth system. This could lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the negative effects of wildﬁres and climate change, including better forestry management, infrastructure resilience, disaster preparedness, and more accurate warning systems.

Previous research has suggested leveraging open Earth Observation (EO) data and advances in Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) to tackle Earth system problems, including wildﬁre modeling. However, there is a limited amount of open-access datasets that combine variables related to fire drivers and burned areas. Existing datasets are often focused on specific regions. For example, a dataset for daily wildﬁre forecasting in the Eastern Mediterranean has been presented, as well as fire occurrence prediction datasets covering the continental US. A fire spread dataset covering the US has also been made available. The limited number of published datasets and challenges in framing wildﬁre forecasting as an ML task have hindered the development of DL-related works on this problem.

Previous studies have used DL models to forecast daily wildﬁre activity in the US, forecast fire danger in the Eastern Mediterranean, predict monthly fire in Africa, and predict global fire emissions on a sub-seasonal to seasonal scale. In this work, we present the SeasFire Cube, a curated global dataset for wildﬁre modeling from 2001 to 2021, combining historical burned areas and carbon emissions from wildﬁres with variables related to fire drivers. To demonstrate the potential use of the dataset, we frame wildﬁre forecasting as an image segmentation task and train UNET++ DL models to predict the presence of global burned areas.
